***	In keeping with paragraph 10 of General Assembly resolution 77/267, the part consisting of the post and non-post resource requirements (part III) is submitted through the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions for the consideration of the Assembly.

text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

6.1	The Office for Outer Space Affairs is responsible for advancing international cooperation in space activities. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and decisions, including resolutions 1472 A (XIV), 76/3, entitled “The ‘Space2030’ Agenda: space as a driver of sustainable development”, 79/87 on international cooperation in the peaceful uses of outer space and 76/55 on transparency and confidence-building measures in outer space activities, as appropriate.

6.2	The core functions of the Office are: (a) serving as the secretariat of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space and its subsidiary bodies (resolution 1472 A (XIV)), as the executive secretariat of the International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems and its Providers’ Forum (resolutions 61/111 and 64/86) and as the secretariat of the Space Mission Planning Advisory Group (resolution 71/90); (b) implementing the United Nations Programme on Space Applications (resolutions 2601 (XXIV) and 37/90) and the programme on the United Nations Platform for Space-based Information for Disaster Management and Emergency Response (UN-SPIDER) (resolution 61/110); (c) maintaining the Register of Objects Launched into Outer Space (resolutions 1721 B (XVI) and 3235 (XXIX)); (d) discharging the responsibilities of the Secretary-General under the United Nations treaties and principles on outer space and related resolutions (resolutions 2222 (XXI), 2345 (XXII), 2777 (XXVI), 3235 (XXIX), 34/68, 37/92, 41/65, 47/68, 59/115 and 62/101); and (e) supporting Member States in fulfilling the “Space2030” Agenda implementation plan (resolution 76/3).
Programme of work
Peaceful uses of outer space – Objective

6.3	The objective, to which this programme contributes, is to strengthen international cooperation in the conduct of space activities for peaceful purposes and advance the use of space science and technology and their applications.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

6.4	To contribute to the objective, the Office will support the work of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space and its subsidiary bodies and promote international cooperation in the exploration and use of outer space for peaceful purposes. Specifically, the Office will:

(a)	Provide substantive secretariat services to the Committee, the Scientific and Technical Subcommittee, the Legal Subcommittee, the International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems and its Providers’ Forum and the Space Mission Planning Advisory Group;

(b)	Provide secretariat services to the working groups of the Committee and its subsidiary bodies, including the Working Groups on Legal Aspects of Space Resource Activities and on the Long-term Sustainability of Outer Space Activities and the Action Team on Lunar Activities Consultation;

(c)	Work with Member States, intergovernmental and, where relevant and applicable, non-governmental entities and other partners to promote the peaceful use of outer space, including through: (i) the implementation of the international legal framework governing space activities; (ii) the registration of space objects launched into outer space; (iii) space debris mitigation; (iv) transparency and confidence-building measures in outer space activities, as appropriate; (v) civil satellite-based positioning, navigation, timing and value added services; and (vi) assistance to the Committee in further developing the governance of outer space activities;

(d)	Deliver training events and technical advisory support to assist States, upon their request, and institutions in: (i) enhancing their capacities in areas such as space law and policy, space sustainability, space economy, climate change, environmental monitoring, natural resources management, precision farming and agriculture, water resources, global health, satellite communications, education, space weather, space exploration, astronomy, search and rescue, disaster risk reduction and emergency response, and global navigation satellite systems; and (ii) developing collaborative platforms and promoting knowledge-sharing for space-based solutions;

(e)	Enhance key initiatives, such as the United Nations Space Bridge and the United Nations Space Sustainability Days, to build the capacity of member States of the Committee and facilitate implementation of the international legal framework governing space activities in the lead-up to the convening of the Fourth United Nations Conference on the Exploration and Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (UNISPACE IV);

(f)	Cooperate with the regional centres for space science and technology education affiliated to the United Nations to deliver capacity-building activities and training in space science and technology to support Member States in achieving the Sustainable Development Goals;

(g)	Augment the impact of the work of the Committee and the Office on progress towards achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, through: (i) targeted outreach activities, publications and materials; (ii) exchanges with relevant stakeholders to promote more systematic sharing of space-based data and information to foster sustainable development and space sustainability; and (iii) promotion of the widest possible adherence to, and full compliance with, the Treaty on Principles Governing the Activities of States in the Exploration and Use of Outer Space, including the Moon and Other Celestial Bodies, and of the role of the Committee in discussions on the establishment of new frameworks for space traffic, space debris and space resources;

(h)	Provide support to Member States that express interest in Committee membership with a view to increasing access to space solutions, partnerships and capacity-building, and participation in the governance of outer space activities.
6.5	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	A safer and more sustainable outer space;
(b)	Space-based solutions enabling monitoring of and progress towards the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals;
(c)	Greater understanding, acceptance and application of the international legal framework governing space activities;

(d)	An increased number of countries with access to space and space benefits, in particular developing countries, in using science and technology and related applications, including space-based solutions, to achieve sustainable development, disaster risk reduction and emergency response;
(e)	Greater compatibility and interoperability of global navigation satellite systems;
(f)	Space capabilities being more readily available through strengthened cooperative relationships and new partnerships.

6.6	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the planning assumption that governmental, intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations are able and willing to support the Office in implementing the programme and responding to increased requests for assistance from Member States.

6.7	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Office will, in line with its mandate, pursue new opportunities with established governmental, intergovernmental and non-governmental partners, including space agencies, industry, academia, institutions and other space-related entities, to strengthen the capacity of countries, in particular developing countries, in using space science and technology and their applications. The Office will also pursue cooperative relationships, including with the private sector. It will enhance transparency by regularly informing the Committee of the projects being implemented and of its partnerships with space agencies, governmental and non-governmental organizations and the private sector.

6.8	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will lead the Inter-Agency Meeting on Outer Space Activities (UN-Space) to promote coherence and increase collaboration on space-related work among entities of the United Nations system, including through the establishment of an inter-agency hub for procurement of earth observation imagery, with a view to better coordinating data-sharing and cooperation on the procurement of space-based information.

6.9	The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, as demonstrated by its Space for Women project, which serves to promote the empowerment of women and girls in space science, technology, innovation and exploration and to increase awareness of education and career opportunities in science, technology, engineering and mathematics. The Office will work with partners to strengthen the capacity and skills of individuals and institutions, with an emphasis on enhancing the participation and retention of women and girls in space activities.

6.10	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will promote inclusive practices for the employment of persons with disabilities in the space sector, as well as innovative tools and technologies to enable accessibility for people with disabilities.
Evaluation activities
6.11	The following evaluations conducted by the Office and completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Strategic evaluation and review of the mandate of the Office;
(b)	Evaluation of the Access to Space for All initiative;
(c)	Evaluation of the Space for Women initiative.

6.12	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, the Office will prioritize actions and activities aimed at better addressing Member States’ needs and promoting a more inclusive space governance, as outlined in result 3. The Office will also strengthen the implementation of its Space for Women portal through the use of project management tools, development of actionable and localized outcomes from expert meetings and enhanced communication of the project objectives in line with United Nations standards by promoting greater audience diversity. To ensure that the Access to Space for All initiative continues to foster innovation and contribute meaningfully to global capacity-building, the Office will strengthen relationships with key stakeholders, increase outreach to underrepresented groups, integrate emerging technologies, refine evaluation and feedback mechanisms and enhance post-programme support for participants and their institutions.
6.13	An evaluation by the Office of its Space Law for New Space Actors project is planned for 2026.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced preparedness for natural disasters in small island developing States

6.14	Small island developing states face significant risks from natural hazards and extreme weather events, making disaster preparedness a critical priority. At the request of Tonga, the Office and the Committee on Earth Observation Satellites collaborated with the country’s disaster management authorities to develop a dedicated portal to receive satellite imagery and provide a platform for visualization of that data in support of decision-making. The online platform, which was validated and refined to align its content with national priorities, integrates satellite data on multiple hazards, such as sea-level rise, ground subsidence, tsunamis and land cover change, with high-resolution imagery to map critical infrastructure like road networks and buildings. In addition, the Office facilitated the delivery, by a private sector partner, of a digital twin of the main island of Tonga, which features three-dimensional representation of buildings and landscapes and enables projections of flood levels, to support future disaster risk reduction planning. Dedicated training sessions, led by the Office, equipped local stakeholders to leverage the platform effectively.
6.15	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 6.1).
Table 6.1
Performance measure

table_content.text: Enhanced preparedness for natural disasters through the adoption of satellite data and associated analysis for disaster preparedness initiatives in Tonga

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: direct access to space-based emergency response mechanisms – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

6.16	The programme’s work contributed to 24 national disaster management agencies becoming authorized users of the International Charter on Space and Major Disasters, which did not meet the planned target of 27. The target was not met because only one official request was received.
6.17	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 6.I).
Figure 6.I
Performance measure: number of national disaster management agencies becoming authorized users of the International Charter on Space and Major Disasters (cumulative)
Result 2: increased access to space – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
6.18	The programme’s work contributed to the launch of five satellites into outer space through the Access to Space for All initiative, which met the planned target.
6.19	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 6.II).
Figure 6.II
Performance measure: number of satellites launched into outer space through the Access to Space for All initiative (cumulative)
Result 3: greater access to space solutions, partnerships, capacity-building and involvement in governance of outer space activities – Proposed programme plan for 2026

6.20	Space technologies are integral to the critical national infrastructure and socioeconomic development of every nation. Every country can benefit from space services and contribute to the future use, safety and sustainability of outer space activities. The programme supports Member States in the exploration and peaceful uses of outer space for economic, social and scientific development, in particular for the benefit of developing countries.
Lessons learned and planned change

6.21	The lesson for the programme was the need to meet the increasing demand from Member States in relation to enhancing their access to space technology, data and applications, as well as to becoming members of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space to contribute to the governance of outer space activities. In applying the lesson, the programme will enhance outreach, organize tailored activities on the safety and sustainability of outer space activities and, when requested, provide guidance on the membership requirements and process.
6.22	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 6.III).
Figure 6.III
Performance measure: number of Member States applying to become members of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (annual)
Legislative mandates

6.26	Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in tables 6.6 to 6.8 and figure 6.IV.

6.27	As shown in tables 6.6 (1) and 6.7 (1), the overall resources proposed for 2026 amount to $5,544,100, reflecting an increase of $1,100 compared with the approved budget for 2025. Resource changes result from other changes. The proposed level of resources provides for the full, efficient and effective implementation of mandates.

children.text: Figure 6.IV
Distribution of proposed resources for 2026
(Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)
Explanation of variances by factor and component – Overall resource changes
Other changes

6.28	As shown in tables 6.6 (1) and 6.7 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $1,100, which relates to the higher standard price of information and communications technology charges for non-field personnel outside of United Nations Headquarters.
Extrabudgetary resources

6.29	As reflected in tables 6.6 (2) and 6.7 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $1,964,900. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for eight posts (3 P-2 or P-1 and 5 General Service (Other level)) to perform the functions of supporting technical advisory services, capacity development activities and other assistance to Member States. In addition, non-post resources would be used to support those areas of work.

6.30	Anticipated in-kind contributions with an estimated value of $2,013,600 reflect Junior Professional Officers, staff provided on a non-reimbursable loan basis, expert support and launch services provided under the Access to Space for All initiative and the value of the provision of office space and conference facilities, meeting services, room and board for participants, transport and other contractual services provided by host countries on a no-cost basis for training events and other activities organized by the Office for Outer Space Affairs.
6.31	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Office in accordance with the delegation of authority from the Secretary-General.
Other information

6.32	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Office for Outer Space Affairs complies with the policies and procedures rolled out by the United Nations Office at Vienna.

6.33	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 6.9. Advance purchasing of some tickets was restricted owing to operational constraints arising from the late availability of extrabudgetary funding sources. The Office for Outer Space Affairs will review late bookings to mitigate instances that have an impact on compliance.
Table 6.9
Compliance rate
(Percentage)

table_content.text: Air tickets purchased at least two weeks before the commencement of travel

children.text: Annex – Organizational structure and post distribution for 2026

Two charts showing the organizational structure of the Office for Outer Space Affairs are presented below. Chart A reproduces the approved organizational structure and post distribution for 2025, as contained in document A/79/6 (Sect. 6), while chart B presents the proposed organizational structure and post distribution for 2026.
Justification for the proposed changes

Office of the Director, United Nations Platform for Space-based Information for Disaster Management and Emergency Response (UN-SPIDER) and the executive secretariat of the International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems. The proposed organizational structure reflects a change in the reporting lines of the Office of the Director, UN-SPIDER and the executive secretariat of the International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems, from the Director to the Deputy Director, to strengthen the Office’s leadership and provide strategic planning, enhance coordination, streamline collaboration across sections, address challenges and new opportunities, improve engagement with external stakeholders for a more focused and agile response and help to streamline operations, ensure efficient decision-making and provide for a clearer chain of command.
A.	Approved organizational structure and post distribution for 2025
a	Junior Professional Officer.

b	Positions on a non-reimbursable loan basis are expected from the Brazilian Air Force, the China National Space Agency, the Government of France, the Government of the Republic of Korea, the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, the Ministry of Emergency Management of China and the United States Department of State.
B.	Proposed organizational structure and post distribution for 2026

Abbreviations: GS (OL), General Service (Other level); ICG, International Committee on Global Navigation Satellite Systems; NRL, non-reimbursable loan; RB, regular budget; UN-SPIDER, United Nations Platform for Space-based Information for Disaster Management and Emergency Response; XB, extrabudgetary.
